user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_ip_count_unlock:
```c
static void
MHD_ip_count_unlock (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon)
{
  mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->master);
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&daemon->per_ip_connection_mutex);
#else
  (void) daemon;
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_ip_count_unlock:
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
...
#define MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_(pmutex) do{if(!MHD_mutex_unlock_(pmutex))MHD_PANIC(_("Failed to unlock mutex.\n"));\
}while(0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No occurrences of the Standard Library function memcmp (or any string comparison using memcmp) exist in the provided function MHD_ip_count_unlock or in the related macro definitions shown. The function body either calls MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (when threading is enabled) or explicitly discards the daemon parameter; the mhd_assert macro is a no-op ((void)0). The MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ macro expands to a conditional call to MHD_mutex_unlock_ and MHD_PANIC with a string literal; neither expansion uses memcmp or performs comparisons of null-terminated strings. Therefore there are no fragments in the supplied code that need investigation for Rule 21.14. If memcmp is used elsewhere in the codebase (not provided here), those locations would need to be inspected, but none are present in the submitted fragments.
